abstracts.cdata!:
The Monrovia Water Supply Project in
            Liberia was implemented. The Bank maintained a firm position
            on scaling down the size of the project to meet
            Monrovia's immediate needs while the institutional
            structure was being enhanced to become capable of managing a
            more extensive long-term expansion program. The Bank also
            remained firm in insisting that all feasible alternatives be
            evaluated in order to identify the best possible approach to
            meet the project's objective. The physical components
            of the project have been very successfully completed. The
            management improvement/technical assistance component of the
            project was useful in that it enhanced the Liberia Water and
            Sewer Corporation (LWSC)'s ability to manage operations
            and construction during critical periods of project
            implementation, but unfortunately it did not produce the
            significant long-term institutional improvements envisioned
            at appraisal. Political and economic factors outside of
            LWSC's and the Bank's control certainly were
            responsible, at least in part, for the failure of this
            component to fully meet its stated objectives. Even more
            significant, LWSC's lack of support and enthusiasm for
            this component was not overcome in the course of project
            supervision and ultimately became a self-fulfilling prophecy.
